text: Amount of sheen to add, per channel. When this node is used as top material on a layer node, the more sheen is added, the less energy will be transmitted to the base material.
Amount of sheen to add, per channel. When this node is used as top material on a layer node, the more sheen is added, the less energy will be transmitted to the base material.
Roughness of the sheen effect. Very rough sheen can be used to create a rough diffuse look (when combined with a diffuse node by a layer or mix).
Shading normal, typically defined by bump or normal mapping. Defaults to the smooth surface normal if not set.
Shading normal, typically defined by bump or normal mapping. Defaults to the smooth surface normal if not set.

Indicates how much energy should be added to compensate for the loss inherent to the sheen model, ranging from no compensation at all, to the expected energy from multiple scattering between the micro-facets.This prevents overly dark results when roughness is high.
When enabled, shadowing from bumped normals is considered. This helps to soften harsh shadow terminators.
Indicates whether this lobe should be considered as specular or diffuse in all shading AOVs.
Defines the name that can be used in LPE AOVs for this lobe. Note that if the name contains the substring 'spec' (case insensitive), it will be considered as a specular lobe, and diffuse otherwise.
Defines the name that can be used by the matte system, to output the weight of this lobe in the final material as an AOV.
